author: nashatyrev
content:
Probably a dumb question: what is the goal of using a _secret_ round key for custody bit calculation? 
To avoid piggy backing of custody bit by other attesters (validator dilemma) it seems that using a publicly available round key is enough. 
Is it just to mitigate custody bit calculation outsourcing?

author: ralexstokes
content: right, the round key should be secret, otherwise someone else (like infura) can manage the custody for you -- anyone who has this key other than the validator imposes counterparty risk to that validator and moreover, there are even slashing conditions around key reveal

author: ralexstokes
content: without this, the actual "custody" property of this construction would be a lot weaker

author: ralexstokes
content: validators can proceed to outsource custody of shard data under this game but they are certainly taking on a large amount of counterparty risk

author: nashatyrev
content:
<@!539495253418180618> thanks for explanation! 
BTW what is the major drawback of custody outsourcing? Centralization? Weakening data availability guarantees? 
I mean why we aim to prevent it?

author: ralexstokes
content: yeah, all of the above -- if i can outsource my data custody then fewer distinct entities contribute to the data availability, so the system overall becomes weaker

author: ralexstokes
content: the proof of custody game is meant to incentivize validators to hold data relevant for consensus (the subtext being these nodes can also host/share the data on demand)
